{{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Masculism sidebar |expanded=topics}} [[Discrimination]] against [[Man|men]] based on gender has been observed in the health and education sectors due to [[stereotypes]] that men are dangerous to women and children. In the legal system, men on average receive [[Sentencing disparity|higher rates of incarceration]] and longer sentences than women for similar crimes.
Research on discrimination against men has been limited, and the topic is little discussed due to cultural biases. Equality measures often pay little or no attention to discrimination against men, which is perceived as morally less serious than [[discrimination against women]].<ref name="Feess 2021" />
== Workforce == There is limited research about discrimination against men in the workplace, and the [[OECD]] often does not consider men when measuring gender equality. Eurofound's European Working Conditions Survey (EWCS) in 2015 showed that 1% of men and 3.1% of women had perceived discrimination in the past 12 months.<ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018">{{Cite web |last1=Fric |first1=Karel |last2=Galli Da Bino |first2=Camilla |date=27 March 2018 |title=Discrimination against men at work: Experiences in five countries |url=https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/en/publications/2018/discrimination-against-men-work-experiences-five-countries |access-date=21 June 2024 |publisher=European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions |format=PDF |location=Dublin}}</ref> Discrimination against men in regards to hiring typically happens in occupations which have the gender role of being feminine.<ref name="Riach 2006" /> Discrimination against men in female-dominated workplaces is more prevalent than discrimination against women in male-dominated workplaces.{{sfn|Riach and Rich|2002|p=503}} Employers may consider that men taking time off means that they are not committed to their job, whereas women taking time off is considered normal. Discrimination can also take the form of stricter dress codes for men.<ref name="Fric 2018">{{Cite web |last=Fric |first=Karel |date=1 May 2018 |title=What about men? |url=https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/fr/blog/2018/what-about-men |access-date=21 June 2024 |publisher=European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions}}</ref>
For a long time in the [[United States]], the idea of discrimination against men was perceived by lawyers and judges as laughable. However, through the efforts of the lawyer [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]], the anti-stereotyping theory was developed. According to this theory, sex stereotyping, which is often experienced by both men and women in the workplace, can be considered sex-based discrimination. This approach has become the norm in US judicial practice after a [[landmark decision]] [[Price Waterhouse v. Hopkins]].<ref name="Franklin 2010">{{Cite journal |last=Franklin |first=C. |year=2010 |title=The anti-stereotyping principle in constitutional sex discrimination law |journal=NYU Law Review |volume=85 |page=83}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Leskinen |first1=E. A. |last2=Rabelo |first2=V. C. |last3=Cortina |first3=L. M. |year=2015 |title=Gender stereotyping and harassment: A "catch-22" for women in the workplace |journal=Psychology, Public Policy, and Law |volume=21 |issue=2 |page=192|doi=10.1037/law0000040 }}</ref> And the decision in [[Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services]] has determined that it can also be considered sex-based discrimination when people discriminate against people of the same sex.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Wiener |first1=R. L. |last2=Bennett |first2=S. |last3=Cheloha |first3=C. |last4=Nicholson |first4=N. |year=2012 |title=Gender policing: Harassment judgments when men target other men |journal=Psychology, Public Policy, and Law |volume=18 |issue=2 |page=245 |doi=10.1037/a0025904}}</ref> The [[feminist movement]] has made a major contribution to the promotion of the anti-stereotyping principle.<ref name="Franklin 2010" />
In 2006 researchers of the English labour market sent out CVs with equal qualifications, ages and experience and concluded that the feminine gender role job of secretaries discriminated against men with hiring, but the study also found 'mixed occupations' with discrimination against men: trainee chartered accountants and computer analyst programmers.<ref name="Riach 2006">{{Cite journal |last=Riach |first=Peter A |date=2006 |title=An Experimental Investigation of Sexual Discrimination in Hiring in the English Labor Market |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/4908229 |journal=Advances in Economic Analysis & Policy |volume=6 |issue=2 |doi=10.2202/1538-0637.1416 |s2cid=9063373 |via=Researchgate}}</ref> Some believe that this may be due to [[affirmative action]].<ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018" />
According to the [[Observatory of Inequalities]], in France men are put under more pressure in work and expected to work long hours and full time. Men are also have higher rates of accidents. They called this '[[reverse sexism]]'.<ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018" />
In a study published in 2019, researchers looked at gender discrimination in 134 countries, and claimed that in 91 (68%) of those countries, men were more disadvantaged than women. They argued that the [[Global Gender Gap Report|Global Gender Gap]] measure was flawed as weightings often did not include situations where men are disadvantaged, and due to a low level of research about men. They based their claim about more men being disadvantaged due to levels that disproportionately affect men and boys, such as receiving harsher punishments than the same crimes of women, overrepresentation in the homeless and prison population, compulsory military service (both in the present and living history), higher levels of suicide, higher levels of drug and alcohol abuse, more occupational deaths, underperformance in education, being overrepresented in dangerous jobs, and experiencing higher rates of physical assault.<ref name="Stoet 2019">{{Cite journal |last1=Stoet |first1=Gijsbert |last2=Geary |first2=David C. |date=2019-01-03 |title=A simplified approach to measuring national gender inequality |journal=PLOS ONE |language=en |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=e0205349 |bibcode=2019PLoSO..1405349S |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0205349 |issn=1932-6203 |pmc=6317789 |pmid=30605478 |doi-access=free}}</ref>
People have a more negative attitude toward discrimination against women when hiring than to discrimination against men.<ref name="Feess 2021" /> People are also more concerned about the shortage of women in occupations dominated by men (usually [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]]) than the shortage of men in fields dominated by women (such as healthcare and education). Men are often sanctioned in the form of condemnation and ridicule for their interest in traditionally feminine professions.{{sfn|Ku|2009|p=748}} Writing in [[Frontiers in Psychology]], psychologist Francesca Manzi points out that in such cases, discrimination against men is often not recognised, which may be due to traditional gender attitudes that prohibit men from traditionally feminine behaviour.{{sfn|Manzi|2019}}
A meta-study published in 2023 in the ''[[Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes]]'' journal looking at 361,645 job applications from 1976 to 2020 concluded that selection bias against male candidates in female‐typed jobs had been stable, saying that "selection bias in favour of male over female candidates was eliminated and, if anything, slightly reversed in sign starting in 2009 for mixed-gender and male-stereotypical jobs". The study also asked both laypeople and scientists to forecast gender bias, who did not predict that discrimination against male candidates be stable, and overestimated bias against female candidates.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Schaerer |first1=Michael |last2=du Plessis |first2=Christilene |last3=Nguyen |first3=My Hoang Bao |last4=van Aert |first4=Robbie C. M. |last5=Tiokhin |first5=Leo |last6=Lakens |first6=Daniël |last7=Giulia Clemente |first7=Elena |last8=Pfeiffer |first8=Thomas |last9=Dreber |first9=Anna |last10=Johannesson |first10=Magnus |last11=Clark |first11=Cory J. |last12=Luis Uhlmann |first12=Eric |date=2023-11-01 |title=On the trajectory of discrimination: A meta-analysis and forecasting survey capturing 44 years of field experiments on gender and hiring decisions |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0749597823000560 |journal=Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes |volume=179 |pages=104280 |doi=10.1016/j.obhdp.2023.104280 |issn=0749-5978 |hdl-access=free |hdl=10023/28715}}</ref>
=== Nursing === Discrimination against men has been described in the healthcare sector due to gender stereotypes and prejudice.<ref name="James 2017" /> In a study of male nurses educators, discrimination was described as a common practice. It included rejection from patients, rejection to support career prospects from hospital management, and having to pay their own expenses during education where female students received stipends. Negative experiences of male nurses included rejection, discrimination, accusations from patients and families; harassment and lack of support from female colleagues, managers, and educators.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Zeb |first1=Hussan |last2=Younas |first2=Ahtisham |last3=Rasheed |first3=Sobia Praveen |last4=Sundus |first4=Amara |date=2020 |title=Lived Experiences of Male Nurse Educators: An Interpretive Phenomenological Inquiry |url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.profnurs.2019.10.005 |url-status=live |journal=Journal of Professional Nursing |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=134–140 |doi=10.1016/j.profnurs.2019.10.005 |pmid=32527635 |s2cid=209282732 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825032305/https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S8755722319301723?via%3Dihub |archive-date=2023-08-25 |access-date=2023-08-18 |via=Science Direct}}</ref><ref name="Moss-Racusin 2024">{{Cite journal |last1=Moss-Racusin |first1=Corinne A. |last2=Rapp |first2=Samantha A. |last3=Brown |first3=Sophie S. |last4=O'Brien |first4=Kerry A. |last5=Croft |first5=Alyssa |date=2024 |title=Gender equality eliminates gender gaps in engagement with female-stereotypic domains. |journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied |volume=30 |issue=1 |pages=62–73 |doi=10.1037/xap0000459 |issn=1939-2192 |pmid=36548086}}</ref>
After the 'feminisation of nursing' in the 19th century, it became socially inappropriate for males to provide intimate care for female patients, such as inserting a catheter. It was also theorised that men were not fit for nursing because the rough hands of men were "not fitted to touch, bathe and dress wounded limbs". Some people view that male nurses do not confirm to the traditional gender stereotyped role that women are the caretakers, and many consider nursing to be a women-only profession.<ref name="James 2017">{{Cite journal |last=James |first=Ross |date=2017 |title=Perceptions of men in the nursing profession: historical and contemporary issues |url=https://openjournals.ljmu.ac.uk/index.php/lhsc/article/view/83/130 |url-status=live |journal=Links to Health and Social Care |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=4–20 |doi=10.24377/LJMU.lhsc.vol2iss1article83 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230818011004/https://openjournals.ljmu.ac.uk/index.php/lhsc/article/view/83/130 |archive-date=2023-08-18 |access-date=2023-08-18 |via=openjournals}}</ref>
In 2006, a male nurse won a discriminatory case against the [[National Health Service]] which refused to let him perform procedures on women without a female chaperone. Female nurses did not have this rule.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Carvel |first=John |date=2006-06-09 |title=Former male nurse wins sex discrimination case |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2006/jun/10/equality.health |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230818061349/https://www.theguardian.com/society/2006/jun/10/equality.health |archive-date=2023-08-18 |access-date=2023-08-18 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== Teachers === Compared to identical women, male elementary school teachers are perceived as having a greater safety threat to children, less likeable and less hirable.<ref name="Moss-Racusin 2024" />
A 2016 survey on the education workplace in Denmark found that 64% of men compared to 39% of women had rules to stop them from sexually assaulting the children, the most common being closing doors while changing nappies. It also found that 10% of men compared to 3% of women were not allowed to be with the children alone and 17% of men reported that there were rules for men only in their workplace. 35% of men and 24% of women had rules constraining physical contact with children, such as kissing and hugging. The survey also reported that 50% of men compared to 15% of women restrained from doing certain activities with children in fear of suspicion of inappropriate conduct. This included not having a baby on their lap, not changing nappies and not kissing a child.<ref name="James 2017" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Regler for fysisk kontakt med børnene i daginstitutioner - FOA |url=https://www.foa.dk/~/media/faelles/pdf/rapporter-undersoegelser/2016/regler%20for%20fysisk%20kontakt%20pdf.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221026111856/https://www.foa.dk/~/media/faelles/pdf/rapporter-undersoegelser/2016/regler%20for%20fysisk%20kontakt%20pdf.pdf |archive-date=2022-10-26 |access-date=2023-08-18}}</ref><ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018" />
=== Quotaism === {{Further|Quotaism}} In 2021, the [[Crime and Corruption Commission]] of [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], said that due to the [[Australian police|Police]]'s strategy on 50/50 recruitment, 200 male candidates were discriminated against. They said that women ineligible for the applied position were selected over men who were eligible.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-05-12 |title=Queensland police discriminated against 200 potential male recruits in favour of women, report finds |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/may/12/queensland-police-discriminated-against-200-potential-male-recruits-in-favour-of-women-report-finds |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819052621/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/may/12/queensland-police-discriminated-against-200-potential-male-recruits-in-favour-of-women-report-finds |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077 |agency=Australian Associated Press}}</ref>
== Education == Historically men received more education than women, but in recent years women have outnumbered men in tertiary education in almost all countries.<ref name="Vincent-Lancrin 2008" />
A study looking at children born in the 1980s in the United States until their adulthood found that boys with behavioural problems were less likely to complete high school and university than girls with the same behavioural problems. Boys had more exposure to negative experiences and peer pressure, and had higher rates of grade repetition. Owens, who conducted the study, attributes this to negative stereotypes about boys and says that this may partially explain the gender gap in education.<ref name="Owens 2016">{{Cite journal |last=Owens |first=Jayanti |date=2016 |title=Early Childhood Behavior Problems and the Gender Gap in Educational Attainment in the United States |journal=Sociology of Education |volume=89 |issue=3 |pages=236–258 |doi=10.1177/0038040716650926 |issn=0038-0407 |pmc=6208359 |pmid=30393398}}</ref>
People are also less likely to assist males falling behind in grades than females.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Cappelen |first1=Alexander W. |last2=Falch |first2=Ranveig |last3=Tungodden |first3=Bertil |date=8 March 2019 |title=The Boy Crisis: Experimental Evidence on the Acceptance of Males Falling Behind |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3348981 |url-status=live |journal=NHH Dept. Of Economics Discussion Paper No. 06/2019 |doi=10.2139/ssrn.3348981 |s2cid=150925947 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825032759/https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3348981 |archive-date=25 August 2023 |access-date=18 August 2023 |hdl-access=free |hdl=11250/2589254}}</ref>
=== Grading bias === Multiple studies have shown grading bias against boys, regardless of the examiner's sex. In these studies, examiners were provided no information about the students apart from their name. This includes a 2004 study in [[Israel]] where 9 subjects; in the arts, sciences and mathematics were tested.<ref name="Vincent-Lancrin 2008">{{Cite book |last=Vincent-Lancrin |first=Stéphan |title=Higher Education to 2030 |date=2008 |publisher=OECD Publishing |isbn=978-92-64-04065-6 |volume=1: Demography |location=Paris |pages=265–298 |chapter=The Reversal of Gender Inequalities in Higher Education: An On-going Trend |chapter-url=https://www.oecd.org/education/ceri/41939699.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180329004626/https://www.oecd.org/education/ceri/41939699.pdf |archive-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> A 2020 study of junior high schools in Sweden conducted a similar study, estimating a bias against boys of 23% of a [[standard deviation]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Berg |first1=Petter |last2=Palmgren |first2=Ola |last3=Tyrefors |first3=Björn |date=2020 |title=Gender grading bias in junior high school mathematics. |url=https://doi.org/10.1080/13504851.2019.1646862 |journal=[[Applied Economics Letters]] |volume=27 |issue=11 |pages=915–919 |doi=10.1080/13504851.2019.1646862 |s2cid=201249468 |hdl-access=free |hdl=10419/210904}}</ref> Biasses have also been found in Portuguese and French high schools, and a study of 15-year-olds in Czechia, and in Italy.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Lievore |first1=Ilaria |last2=Triventi |first2=Moris |date=2022-10-17 |title=Do teacher and classroom characteristics affect the way in which girls and boys are graded? |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01425692.2022.2122942 |journal=British Journal of Sociology of Education |volume=44 |issue=1 |pages=97–122 |doi=10.1080/01425692.2022.2122942 |issn=0142-5692 |s2cid=252985585}}</ref> According to a global report performed by the [[OECD]] of over 60 countries, girls were given higher marks in comparison to boys with the same ability.<ref name="u634">{{cite web | last=Coughlan | first=Sean | title=Teachers 'give higher marks to girls' | website=BBC News | date=2015-03-05 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-31751672 | access-date=2024-10-09}}</ref>
A study looking at the perceptions of students by their teachers found that teachers perceive girls as having higher "Persistence, Mood, and [educational competence]" and boys having higher levels of "Activity, Distractibility, Inhibition, and Negative Emotionality".<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Mullola |first1=Sari |last2=Ravaja |first2=Niklas |last3=Lipsanen |first3=Jari |last4=Alatupa |first4=Saija |last5=Hintsanen |first5=Mirka |last6=Jokela |first6=Markus |last7=Keltikangas-Järvinen |first7=Liisa |date=2011-01-17 |title=Gender differences in teachers' perceptions of students' temperament, educational competence, and teachability |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.2044-8279.2010.02017.x |url-status=live |journal=British Journal of Educational Psychology |volume=82 |issue=2 |pages=185–206 |doi=10.1111/j.2044-8279.2010.02017.x |issn=0007-0998 |pmid=22583086 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825032833/https://bpspsychub.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.2044-8279.2010.02017.x |archive-date=2023-08-25 |access-date=2023-08-21}}</ref>
=== Punishment === Due to gender behavioured norms which many schools enforce, boys receive on average higher rates of suspension, expulsion and retention than girls with the same behaviours. This begins in preschool.<ref name="Owens 2016" />
=== Scholarships === In many universities there are scholarships for women only, often known as women's scholarships. These have been described as illegal under [[Title IX]] and discriminatory against men, causing the [[United States Department of Education]] to launch multiple investigations around the country.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-08-21 |title=Do Women STEM College Programs Discriminate Against Males? |url=https://www.govtech.com/education/Do-Women-STEM-College-Programs-Discriminate-Against-Males.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230816044708/https://www.govtech.com/education/do-women-stem-college-programs-discriminate-against-males.html |archive-date=2023-08-16 |access-date=2023-08-16 |website=GovTech |language=en}}</ref>
In a study of 220 universities in the United States, 84% of them offered single-gender scholarships. The study described the universities as discriminatory if there are 4 or more women-only scholarships compared to men-only, and described 68.5% of the universities as discriminatory against men.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-11-03 |title=Scholarships |url=https://www.saveservices.org/equity/scholarships/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230816044706/https://www.saveservices.org/equity/scholarships/ |archive-date=2023-08-16 |access-date=2023-08-16 |website=Save - Leading The Policy Movement For Fairness and Due Process On Campus |language=en-US}}</ref> People pushing to get these removed have mentioned that these scholarships were created in the 1970s when women were under-represented in tertiary education, but it is now men who underperform and that the scholarships should become gender-neutral.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Elsesser |first=Kim |title=Women's Scholarships And Awards Eliminated To Be Fair To Men |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kimelsesser/2022/04/13/womens-scholarships-and-awards-eliminated-to-be-fair-to-men/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230816044709/https://www.forbes.com/sites/kimelsesser/2022/04/13/womens-scholarships-and-awards-eliminated-to-be-fair-to-men/ |archive-date=2023-08-16 |access-date=2023-08-16 |website=Forbes |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2009-01-31 |title=Women-only scholarships under spotlight |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/540737/Women-only-scholarships-under-spotlight |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230816045146/https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/540737/Women-only-scholarships-under-spotlight |archive-date=2023-08-16 |access-date=2023-08-16 |website=Stuff |language=en}}</ref>
In 2008 the [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|Human Rights Commission]] of New Zealand considered abolishing women's scholarships.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2008-07-20 |title=Should female-only scholarships be abolished? |url=https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/national/9665/should-female-only-scholarships-be-abolished |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230816045147/https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/national/9665/should-female-only-scholarships-be-abolished |archive-date=2023-08-16 |access-date=2023-08-16 |website=RNZ |language=en-nz}}</ref>
== Law and legal system ==
=== Pension === In 2022 the [[European Court of Human Rights]] found that the Swiss government discriminates against men. Women whose husbands die receive a pension for the rest of their lives whereas men only receive a pension if they have children under the age of 18. The law is expected to be rewritten.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-10-11 |title=Switzerland discriminating against men on pension benefits, ECHR finds |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-63217557 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819041203/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-63217557 |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |work=BBC News |language=en-GB}}</ref>
In [[Cyprus]], men cannot receive the pension of a dead person, but women can.<ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018" />
Between 1940 and 1991 in the [[United Kingdom]], the pension age was different for men and women. It was 65 for men and 60 for women, although this has now changed.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Background relating to changes in State Pension age for women {{!}} Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman (PHSO) |url=http://www.ombudsman.org.uk/publications/womens-state-pension-age-our-findings-department-work-and-pensions-communication/background-relating-changes-state-pension-age-women |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230601115955/https://www.ombudsman.org.uk/publications/womens-state-pension-age-our-findings-department-work-and-pensions-communication/background-relating-changes-state-pension-age-women |archive-date=2023-06-01 |access-date=2023-08-21 |website=www.ombudsman.org.uk |language=en}}</ref> This also had an effect on bus free passes where women previously could get them at a younger age than men.<ref>{{Cite web |date=18 November 1998 |title=House of Commons Hansard Written Answers for 18 Nov 1998 |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199798/cmhansrd/vo981118/text/81118w24.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028125230/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199798/cmhansrd/vo981118/text/81118w24.htm |archive-date=28 October 2016 |access-date=21 August 2023 |website=publications.parliament.uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=25 March 1976 |title=Sex Equality (Bus Fares) |url=https://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/1976-03-25/debates/cdc23d6b-3daa-4a14-b764-e0cc28928830/SexEquality(BusFares) |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230822004855/https://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/1976-03-25/debates/cdc23d6b-3daa-4a14-b764-e0cc28928830/SexEquality(BusFares) |archive-date=22 August 2023 |access-date=22 August 2023 |website=hansard.parliament.uk}}</ref>
=== Retirement age === The retirement age in many countries is lower for women than for men. This has been criticised because generally women have a higher life expectancy and because, even if the retirement age was equal, men have less time in retirement.<ref name="Stoet 2019" /> This included Switzerland where the retirement age for men was 65 whereas the retirement age was 64 for women.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-04 |title=Chart of the week: Swiss retirement age compared |url=https://lenews.ch/2022/03/04/chart-of-the-week-swiss-retirement-age-compared/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819041722/https://lenews.ch/2022/03/04/chart-of-the-week-swiss-retirement-age-compared/ |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |website=Le News |language=en-US}}</ref> The retirement age for women increased to 65 in 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-09-26 |title=Swiss voters back raising the female retirement age to 65 |url=https://www.euronews.com/2022/09/26/swiss-voters-back-raising-the-female-retirement-age-to-65 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819041723/https://www.euronews.com/2022/09/26/swiss-voters-back-raising-the-female-retirement-age-to-65 |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |website=euronews |language=en}}</ref> In a few countries however, the effective age of labour market exit for men is lower than for women, such as Spain, Finland and France.<ref name="Stoet 2019" />
=== Incarceration and sentencing === {{Further|Sentencing disparity}} In the United Kingdom, United States, and France, women who commit crimes are less likely to be arrested, and sent to court than men.<ref name="Philippe 2020" /> Males arrested for murder are six times more likely to face the death penalty than females arrested for murder. Many scholars have suggested that this is due to chivalric beliefs.<ref>{{Citation |title='Chivalry is not Dead: Murder, Gender, and the Death Penalty', Berkeley Journal of Gender Law and Justice, 64, pp. 64–112 |date=2016-12-05 |work=The International Library of Essays on Capital Punishment, Volume 1 |pages=377–426 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9781315238937-30 |access-date=2023-08-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825032839/https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/mono/10.4324/9781315238937-30/chivalry-dead-murder-gender-death-penalty-berkeley-journal-gender-law-justice-64-pp-64%E2%80%93112-peter-hodgkinson |archive-date=2023-08-25 |url-status=live |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781315238937-30 |isbn=978-1-315-23893-7}}</ref>
A study in France of sentences between 2000 and 2003 found that women who committed comparable offenses to men received prison sentences that were 33% shorter. The study suggested that the gender gap is caused by the gender of the judge, rather than the prosecutor.<ref name="Philippe 2020">{{Cite journal |last=Philippe |first=Arnaud |date=2020-01-19 |title=Gender Disparities in Sentencing |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/ecca.12333 |journal=Economica |volume=87 |issue=348 |pages=1037–1077 |doi=10.1111/ecca.12333 |issn=0013-0427 |s2cid=214089653 |hdl-access=free |hdl=1983/27152ffc-61ad-44b1-ae51-2c4541426dcb}}</ref> A 2015 study in the England and Wales found that males were 88% more likely than females to be sent for prison after committing similar crimes. This sex difference varies between crimes. The study found that there was a 35% difference from shoplifting or non-motor theft, and a 362% difference for offences relating to drug trade and production.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Associations between being male or female and being sentenced to prison in England and Wales in 2015 |url=https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/571737/associations-between-sex-and-sentencing-to-prison.pdf |access-date=1 January 2024 |website=[[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]]}}</ref> A 2014 study in ''[[American Law and Economics Review]]'' found that in the United States, men receive 63% longer sentences than women on average, saying that "women are also significantly likelier to avoid charges and convictions, and twice as likely to avoid incarceration if convicted".<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Starr |first=S. B. |date=2014-08-21 |title=Estimating Gender Disparities in Federal Criminal Cases |url=https://doi.org/10.1093/aler/ahu010 |journal=American Law and Economics Review |volume=17 |issue=1 |pages=127–159 |doi=10.1093/aler/ahu010 |issn=1465-7252}}</ref> Women of all races in the United States receive shorter sentences than men.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Demographic Differences in Sentencing: An Update to the 2012 Booker Report |url=https://www.ussc.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/research-and-publications/research-publications/2017/20171114_Demographics.pdf |access-date=1 January 2024 |website=[[United States Sentencing Commission]]}}</ref>
An analysis of the criminal practice of various countries revealed the existence of discrimination against men in criminal and penal enforcement law. In an extensive study of criminal practice in New Zealand, it was revealed that male criminals are more likely than female criminals to receive real sentences instead of suspended ones, and it was proved that it is the gender of the defendants that influences sentencing, including taking into account other factors such as criminal record. Judges tend to explain the criminal actions of women by social factors, to find mitigating circumstances in them. UK courts systematically impose lower penalties on women for theft, explaining their concern for their children. This argument is used even when mitigating the punishment of childless women. A similar situation in the United States was recognised by the Ministry of Justice. In Finland, according to the database of the state research institute Optula, men receive longer sentences for similar crimes than women and are less likely to be sentenced to probation.{{sfn|Malmi|2009|p=245—247}}
In Russia, the law prohibits the death penalty and [[life imprisonment]] for women, but not for men. Also, only men are subject to detention in strict and special regime [[Corrective labor colony|correctional colonies]]. Convicted women are kept in general regime correctional colonies, regardless of the severity of the crime they committed.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Karamanukyan |first=David |date=2019 |title=Законодательные предпосылки гендерной дискриминации в Российской Федерации |trans-title=Legislative prerequisites for gender discrimination in the Russian Federation |journal=Vestnik of the Omsk Law Academy |language=ru |volume=16 |issue=1 |issn=2306-1340}}</ref> Rima Torosyan, a legal scholar, argues that the lack of differentiation in the issue of assigning the type of correctional institution for women is a violation of the principles of humanism and justice. She points out that the absence of this differentiation does not contribute to the [[Rehabilitation (penology)|rehabilitation]] of convicted women. She also believes that the fact that women commit crimes less often than men does not mean that crimes they commit pose a lower level of public danger.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Torosyan |first=Rima |title=Права мужчин и женщин в России: Реализация принципа равенства |date=2019 |publisher=Prospekt |isbn=978-5-392-27453-6 |editor-last=Komkova |editor-first=G. N. |location=Moscow |language=ru |trans-title=Rights of men and women in Russia: Implementation of the principle of equality |chapter=Запрет дискриминации мужчин в уголовной и уголовно-исполнительной сфере |trans-chapter=Prohibition of discrimination against men in the criminal and penal sphere |doi=10.31085/9785392274536-2019-216}}</ref>
=== Rape === {{Main articles|Rape of males}} In multiple countries rape is defined with penetrative sex, which means that by law, men who are forced to penetrate another person, but are not forcibly penetrated, are not considered to be rape victims. ==Discrimination against LGBT men== {{Main|Discrimination against gay men|Discrimination against transgender men}} Male homosexuality is criminalised or prosecuted in more jurisdictions than female homosexuality. There were at least 30 countries in 2002 where female homosexuality was not explicitly criminalised, but male homosexuality was illegal.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Smith |first=Dan |title=The State of the World Atlas |date=2003 |publisher=Penguin Books|pages=62–63}}</ref>{{sfn|Kane|2015|p=276}} Gay men are much more likely than lesbians to become victims of hate crimes. In 2008 the FBI's hate crime statistics show that 58.6% of crimes based on sexual orientation were motivated against gay men, whereas 12% were motivated against lesbians.<ref>{{Cite web |title=FBI - Hate Crime 2008 |url=https://ucr.fbi.gov/hate-crime/2008 |access-date=2 August 2024 |website=FBI}}</ref> Gay men face greater difficulties in adopting children than lesbians, even in countries where same-sex couples are allowed to adopt children.<ref name="Benatar 2012">{{Cite book |last=Benatar |first=David |title=The second sexism: discrimination against men and boys |date=2012 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |isbn=978-0-470-67446-8 |location=Malden, MA |pages=54}}</ref>{{Rp|page=54}}
As gender researcher M. Holleb points out, transgender men face a [[Discrimination against transgender men|specific kind of discrimination]] based on the belief that trans men are actually women. This discrimination includes the invisibility of trans men in society.{{sfn|Holleb|2019}} Researcher E. C. Krell writes about the existence of a racialized transmisandry faced by transgender men of colour living in an atmosphere of strict control over black masculinity.{{sfn|Krell|2017|p=234}}
== Health == {{Further|Men's health}} Military and criminal violence, suicides and industrial accidents are factors that contribute to the reduction of men's life expectancy. The frequency of fatal cases of violence against men and the greater tolerance for violence against men largely explain why men, as a rule, live much less than women. {{Citation needed|date=February 2024}} In almost all countries of the world, men are also more likely than women to commit suicide. In the West and in Western Asian countries, the suicide rate among men is at least twice as high as among women, and sometimes the gap is even greater. Men also make up the majority of victims of fatal industrial accidents. In the United States, the death rate at work among men is about ten times higher than among women. Although women account for 43% of the hours worked for wages in the United States, they account for only 7% of accidents at work. The situation is worse in Canada, where men account for about 95% of workplace fatalities. In this country, the number of workplace deaths among men is about 10.4 per 100,000, while the corresponding figure among women is 0.4 per 100,000. In Taiwan, men account for about 93% of workplace fatalities.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Lin |first1=Yen-Hui |last2=Chen |first2=Chih-Yong |last3=Luo |first3=Jin-Lan |date=July 2008 |title=Gender and age distribution of occupational fatalities in Taiwan |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0001457508000791 |journal=Accident Analysis & Prevention |volume=40 |issue=4 |pages=1604–1610 |doi=10.1016/j.aap.2008.04.008 |pmid=18606296 |access-date=2 August 2024}}</ref>
=== Mental health === Much of mental health research is focussed on women instead of men, which has caused scholars to describe problems faced by men as a 'silent epidemic', an 'invisible crisis', or a 'quiet catastrophe'. Men comprise between 75% and 80% of deaths by suicide, and around three quarters of those with substance use disorders. Despite this, only around 30% of people who use mental health services are men.<ref name="Whitley 2018">{{Cite journal |last=Whitley |first=Rob |date=September 2018 |title=Men's Mental Health: Beyond Victim-Blaming |journal=The Canadian Journal of Psychiatry |language=en |volume=63 |issue=9 |pages=577–580 |doi=10.1177/0706743718758041 |issn=0706-7437 |pmc=6109881 |pmid=30141987}}</ref>
Literature on men's mental health has been described by multiple scholars as using an approach that is narrowly focussed that borders on [[victim blaming]], unlike the studies on women's mental health. These often focus on mental health issues being caused by 'masculinity' and the attitudes and behaviours of men rather than "acknowledging a highly complex web of causation". This includes the [[World Health Organization]], who have encouraged 'programmes with men and boys that include deliberate discussions of gender and masculinity'. Scholars have criticised that focussing on masculinity 'blam[es] the victim; undervalu[es] positive male traits; and alienat[es] men in whom we seek to instil healthy behaviours'.<ref name="Whitley 2018" />
Mental health advertising has been criticised by scholars for blaming men for their mental health issues. For example, the United States [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality]] have made campaigns with the slogan "this year thousands of men will die from stubbornness". The Australian mental health campaign, [[Beyond Blue]] have written "Men are known for bottling things up".<ref name="Whitley 2018" />
=== Circumcision === {{Main|Circumcision controversies}}
Philosopher [[David Benatar]] argues that although [[circumcision|male genital mutilation]] in itself is not discriminatory, there are still several significant aspects of circumcision that can be characterized as discriminatory — among them he refers to the lack of anaesthesia when circumcising boys.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Benatar |first1=Michael |last2=Benatar |first2=David |date=May 2003 |title=Between Prophylaxis and Child Abuse: The Ethics of Neonatal Male Circumcision |journal=The American Journal of Bioethics |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=35–48 |doi=10.1162/152651603766436216 |pmid=12859815}}</ref> He also writes about the contrast when Western society ignores the painful circumcision of boys with the removal of the entire foreskin and at the same time extremely negatively perceives minimally invasive forms of manipulation with the genitals of teenage girls (for example, a symbolic incision of the clitoris without removing any vulva tissues in Somali girls in the USA, which served as an alternative to traditional circumcision).<ref name="Benatar 2012" />{{Rp|page=44–45}}<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Committee on Bioethics |last2=Davis |first2=D. S. |date=1 May 2010 |title=Ritual Genital Cutting of Female Minors |journal=Pediatrics |volume=125 |issue=5 |pages=1088–1093 |doi=10.1542/peds.2010-0187 |pmid=20421257}}</ref>
== Parenting == Less than 10 percent of scientific studies about parents or parenting include fathers, and books about parenting almost exclusively focus on the mother. In an interview of 49 single fathers, they said that they perceived that society does not recognise their status as a single parent. Writing in the [[Family Law Quarterly]] journal, Jerry W. McCant says that society makes little or no effort to teach boys the social skills of nurturing. She described men as apart from their financial contributions, a 'disposable parent', due to society's belief that women are better equipped for parenting and that fathers are not considered parents.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=McCant |first=Jerry W. |date=1987 |title=The Cultural Contradiction of Fathers as Nonparents |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/25739449 |url-status=live |journal=Family Law Quarterly |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=127–143 |issn=0014-729X |jstor=25739449 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230822012409/https://www.jstor.org/stable/25739449 |archive-date=2023-08-22 |access-date=2023-08-22}}</ref>
It is more difficult for gay men to adopt children than for lesbians, even in countries where same-sex adoption is legal.<ref name="Benatar 2012" />{{Rp|page=54}}
Unlike [[motherhood]], fatherhood is not mentioned in [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Berween |first=M. |year=2003 |title=International bills of human rights: an Islamic critique |journal=The International Journal of Human Rights |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=129–142|doi=10.1080/13642980310001726246 }}</ref>
== Gender studies == Discrimination against men has little research due to cultural bias.<ref name="Fric & Galli da Bino 2018" /> The [[Global Gender Gap Index]] has been criticised for only including disadvantages that disproportionately affect women, meaning that the index cannot measure when men are disadvantaged.<ref name="Stoet 2019" /> It also does not penalise countries where girls outperform boys in education for example, treating it as if the genders were equal.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Global Gender Gap Report 2021 |url=https://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GGGR_2021.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221009/https://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GGGR_2021.pdf |archive-date=9 October 2022 |access-date=25 August 2023 |page=72}}</ref>
A relevant example of discrimination is the stigma directed to the deliberation of men being considered as victims of rape or sexual-assault. It is reported that "some feminists reject male rape to validate women’s experience of sexual violence by viewing men as solely offenders".<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Thomas |first1=John C. |last2=Kopel |first2=Jonathan |date=2023-04-03 |title=Male Victims of Sexual Assault: A Review of the Literature |journal=Behavioral Sciences |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=304 |doi=10.3390/bs13040304 |issn=2076-328X |pmc=10135558 |pmid=37102818 |doi-access=free}}</ref>
Factors as such suggest that in order to find reform in gender-based discrimination, an acknowledgement of patriarchal effects on both genders alike. "While the negative impact of patriarchal oppression on women and other minority communities has been long recognized," it is crucial to understand that men also suffer severe detrimental effects from this system.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Gupta |first1=Mayank |last2=Madabushi |first2=Jayakrishna S |last3=Gupta |first3=Nihit |date=2023 |title=Critical Overview of Patriarchy, Its Interferences With Psychological Development, and Risks for Mental Health |journal=Cureus |volume=15 |issue=6 |pages=e40216 |doi=10.7759/cureus.40216 |issn=2168-8184 |pmc=10332384 |pmid=37435274 |doi-access=free}}</ref>
== Perceptions == Several studies have shown that people judge discrimination against women as morally worse than discrimination against men.<ref name="Feess 2021">{{Cite journal |last1=Feess |first1=Eberhard |last2=Feld |first2=Jan |last3=Noy |first3=Shakked |date=2021 |title=People Judge Discrimination Against Women More Harshly Than Discrimination Against Men – Does Statistical Fairness Discrimination Explain Why? |journal=[[Frontiers in Psychology]] |volume=12 |page=675776 |doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2021.675776 |pmc=8488152 |pmid=34616329 |doi-access=free}}</ref> People also have less of a concern about the under-representation of men in healthcare, early-education and domestic careers than the under-representation of women in [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Block |first1=Katharina |last2=Croft |first2=Alyssa |last3=De Souza |first3=Lucy |last4=Schmader |first4=Toni |title=Do people care if men don't care about caring? The asymmetry in support for changing gender roles |journal=Journal of Experimental Social Psychology}}</ref>
Due to the attribution error of the gender group, the negative behaviour shown by representatives of both sexes is perceived as characteristic and typical only for men. People tend to attribute negative intra-group female behaviour to environmental variables, while negative extra-group male behaviour is attributed solely to personal characteristics.{{sfn|Siddiqi|2021|p=213}}
Researchers Alice Eagly and Antonio Mladinik introduced the [[women-are-wonderful effect]] in 1994 after they found that both men and women tend to attribute positive traits to women, with women showing a much more pronounced bias. Positive traits were attributed to men by both sexes too, but to a much lesser extent. They found this trend in their 1989 and 1991 studies, which used questionnaires distributed to students in the United States.{{sfn|Eagly|1994|p=13}}
In an online survey 22,508 adults in 33 countries, conducted by [[Ipsos]] between 2022 and 2023, 48% of people believed that the promotion of women's rights has gone as far as discriminating against men.<ref>{{Cite web |title=International Women's Day 2023 Full Report |url=https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2023-03/International%20Women%27s%20Day%202023%20-%20full%20report.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230528195713/https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2023-03/International%20Women%27s%20Day%202023%20-%20full%20report.pdf |archive-date=28 May 2023 |access-date=24 August 2023}}</ref> A third of American men believe that they are discriminated against.<ref name="Reeves 2022" />{{Rp|120}}
==Conscription== {{Main|Conscription and sexism}} Opponents of discrimination against men,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Berlatsky |first=Noah |date=May 29, 2013 |title=When Men Experience Sexism |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/05/when-men-experience-sexism/276355/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105151244/http://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/05/when-men-experience-sexism/276355/ |archive-date=January 5, 2015 |access-date=April 26, 2015 |website=[[The Atlantic]]}}</ref><ref name="James 2017" />{{Rp|102}} including some [[feminist]]s,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Stephen |first=Lynn |date=1981 |title=Making the Draft a Women's Issue |url=http://voices.revealdigital.com/cgi-bin/independentvoices?a=d&d=BGJGDDE19761001.1.59&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN---------------1 |journal=Women: A Journal of Liberation |volume=8 |issue=1 |access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Lindsey |first=Karen |url=https://archive.org/details/reweavingwebofli00mcal |title=Reweaving the Web of Life: Feminism and Nonviolence |date=1982 |publisher=New Society Publishers |isbn=978-0-86571-016-0 |editor-last=McAllister |editor-first=Pam |chapter=Women and the Draft |chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/reweavingwebofli00mcal |url-access=registration |chapter-url-access=registration}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Levertov |first=Denise |url=https://archive.org/details/candlesinbabylon00leve |title=Candles in Babylon |date=1982 |publisher=New Directions Press |isbn=978-0-8112-0831-4 |chapter=A Speech: For Antidraft Rally, D.C. March 22, 1980 |chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/candlesinbabylon00leve |url-access=registration |chapter-url-access=registration}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=CODEPINK Opposes Compulsory Draft Registration for All Genders |url=https://www.codepink.org/codepink_opposes_compulsory_draft_registration_for_all_genders |access-date=24 November 2019 |website=Codepink.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Sun |first=Rivera |title=Women's Draft? Sign Me Up To Abolish War |url=https://www.codepink.org/women_s_draft_sign_me_up_to_abolish_war |access-date=24 November 2019 |website=Codepink.org}}</ref> have criticised military [[conscription]], or compulsory military service, as [[Sexism|sexist]]. At the same time, the existing gender equality indices do not take into account gender-based mandatory conscription in peacetime for men.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Heikkilä |first1=Jussi |last2=Laukkanen |first2=Ina |date=2022 |title=Gender-specific Call of Duty: A Note on the Neglect of Conscription in Gender Equality Indices |journal=Defence and Peace Economics |language=en |volume=33 |issue=5 |pages=603–615 |arxiv=2201.09270 |doi=10.1080/10242694.2020.1844400 |s2cid=229449157 |doi-access=free}}</ref>
Military registration only for men in the United States is one of the examples that men's rights activist [[Warren Farrell]] cites to argue that discrimination against men is pervasive. He writes that if any other group (for example, Jews, African Americans or women) were chosen at birth to become the only group for which registration for potential death would be required, society would call it anti-Semitism, racism or sexism.{{sfn|Farrell|1993|p=14}} according to Farrell, men absorb society's ideas about military duty as a path to glory and power, and as a result do not consider it as discrimination.{{sfn|Farrell|1993|p=60}}
=== Selective service === In 1981, the U.S. Supreme Court in the [[Rostker v. Goldberg]] case recognised the constitutional practice of military registration of only the male part of the country's population, arguing that women could not serve in positions related to direct participation in hostilities. However, in 2015, the Pentagon lifted all restrictions on military service for women. In this regard, National Coalition For Men filed a lawsuit on the unconstitutionality of military registration aimed only at men, considering this practise discriminatory: men who do not register in [[Selective Service System]] at the age of 18 may be denied state benefits, such as employment in federal organisations and student loans. As a result, on February 22, 2019, a federal court in Texas agreed with human rights defenders, recognizing the current system of military registration in the United States unconstitutional.<ref>{{Cite web |date=24 February 2019 |title=With women in combat roles, a federal court rules male-only draft unconstitutional |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/02/24/military-draft-judge-rules-male-only-registration-unconstitutional/2968872002/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200522042244/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/02/24/military-draft-judge-rules-male-only-registration-unconstitutional/2968872002/ |archive-date=2020-05-22 |access-date=2020-05-17 |website=[[USA Today]] |language=en}}</ref> However, this decision was overturned by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hasbrouck |first=Edward |title=Court of Appeals overturns ruling that male-only draft registration requirement is unconstitutional |url=https://hasbrouck.org/blog/archives/002378.html |access-date=23 January 2021 |website=Resisters.Info}}</ref> In June 2021, the US Supreme Court refused to review the decision of the Court of Appeals.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Higgens |first=Tucker |date=June 7, 2021 |title=Supreme Court won't hear case arguing military draft registration discriminates against men |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/07/supreme-court-wont-hear-case-challenging-male-only-draft-registration.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009130909/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/07/supreme-court-wont-hear-case-challenging-male-only-draft-registration.html |archive-date=2021-10-09 |access-date=June 7, 2021 |website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>
=== In the former Soviet Union === {{see also|Dedovshchina}} In Soviet society, universal male military duty played a significant role in the construction of masculinity: Soviet ideas about militarized [[masculinity]] were based on the ideas of civic duty, heroism and patriotism, and Soviet gender ideology defined military service as the most important instance of turning a boy into a man. In post-Soviet Russia, the link between masculinity and militarization, established by the institute of [[conscription]], has undergone significant changes — largely for political and economic reasons. Unlike the Soviet one, the post-Soviet Russian state no longer provides men with the former social guarantees as a reward for militarization, and the state's rupture of the former social contract leads to the reluctance of young men to go to military service. In addition, with the collapse of the Soviet state, militarized masculinity came into conflict with the new capitalist masculinity: many young men believe that military service is incompatible with a dynamic market economy and competition in the labour market. Scientists also state a significant gap between the state ideology of militarized patriotism and the sentiments of the Russian population, a significant part of which is sceptical about post-Soviet military conflicts and does not regard them as fair.{{sfn|Eichler|2011}}
During the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine]] in 2022, the Ukrainian authorities, in order to mobilize men, banned men aged 18 to 60 from leaving the country before the end of hostilities, which is discrimination against men on the basis of gender and violation of human rights.{{sfn|Wojnicka|2023}}<ref name="Storf 2022">{{Cite journal |last=Storf |first=Pia Lotta |date=18 March 2022 |title=Ukraine's Travel Ban, Gender and Human Rights: Gendered Impacts of Conflict and the Right to Leave |url=https://voelkerrechtsblog.org/ukraines-travel-ban-gender-and-human-rights/ |journal=Völkerrechtsblog |language=en |doi=10.17176/20220318-121030-0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220414092610/https://voelkerrechtsblog.org/ukraines-travel-ban-gender-and-human-rights/ |archive-date=2022-04-14 |access-date=2022-05-09}}</ref><ref name="Maguire 2022">{{Cite web |last=Maguire |first=Amy |date=7 March 2022 |title=Why banning men from leaving Ukraine violates their human rights |url=https://theconversation.com/why-banning-men-from-leaving-ukraine-violates-their-human-rights-178411 |access-date=21 June 2024 |website=The Conversation}}</ref> [[2022 Russian mobilization|Partial mobilization in Russia]] is no less discriminatory for men, since it forces them to risk their lives and health and kill other people regardless of their views; at the same time, men who fled mobilization in Russia are not even recognised by other countries as refugees.{{sfn|Wojnicka|2023}}
== Extent and cause == The extent of [[discrimination]] against men in the modern world is the subject of debate in the scientific community.
Sociologist [[Øystein Gullvåg Holter]] characterizes the position of men in the gender hierarchy rather as mixed, but not as purely dominant.{{sfn|Holter|2005|p=115}} Sociologist [[Fred Pincus]] says men may face intentional discrimination, although women are in a less favourable position than men;{{sfn|Pincus|2003|p=140—141}} Pincus also believes that such cases of discrimination against men have nothing to do with positive discrimination.{{sfn|Pincus|2003|p=140—141}} Psychologist Francesca Manzi says that since men are not typically discriminated, unlike women, discrimination against men is more difficult to detect. Estimates of the scale of the phenomenon may depend on discrepancies in the definition of the term "discrimination". According to her, the non-recognition of a number of unfavourable situations by discrimination may be influenced by traditional gender attitudes, which prohibit men from expressing stereotypical feminine behaviour.{{sfn|Manzi|2019}}
In the book ''[[Of Boys and Men]]'', [[Richard Reeves (British author)|Richard Reeves]] writes that while discrimination against men exists, it is not done deliberately. He writes that it was caused by the result of "structural changes in the economy and broader culture, and the failings of our education system".<ref name="Reeves 2022">{{Cite book |last=Reeves |first=Richard |title=Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It |publisher=[[Brookings Institution Press]] |year=2022 |isbn=978-0-8157-3987-6}}</ref>{{Rp|120}}
Psychologist Aman Siddiqi, applying an [[Intersectionality|intersectional]] approach, writes that men do not face bias to the same extent: for example, the manifestation of gender stereotypes, such as the perception of men as dangerous and aggressive, will vary depending on race.{{sfn|Siddiqi|2021|p=230—231}}
== Others ==
=== Airline seating === {{Main|Airline seating sex discrimination controversy}} [[Air New Zealand]], [[Virgin Australia]] and [[Qantas]] banned men from sitting next to unaccompanied children in planes.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-20 |title=Ban on men sitting next to children |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/ban-on-men-sitting-next-to-children/NNJTPQDPA22Y4UKXVRHA5M6I34/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230820033840/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/ban-on-men-sitting-next-to-children/NNJTPQDPA22Y4UKXVRHA5M6I34/ |archive-date=2023-08-20 |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=NZ Herald |language=en-NZ}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last1=Jabour |first1=Bridie |last2=Horin |first2=Adele |date=2012-08-10 |title=Virgin policy change after male passenger was moved away from children |url=https://www.theage.com.au/national/virgin-policy-change-after-male-passenger-was-moved-away-from-children-20120810-23zr1.html |access-date=2024-02-18 |website=The Age |language=en}}</ref> They were criticised for promoting the idea that all men are pedophiles and removing the distinction between caring family men and pedophiles. It also associated all men with the actions of the minority of men. The policy was criticised for using the health of children to justify discrimination against men. It was described by multiple accounts of men that such policies made them afraid of being falsely accused of child abuse or paedophillia.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Hodgetts |first1=Darrin |last2=Rua |first2=Mohi |date=2008 |title=Media and community anxieties about men's interactions with children |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/casp.965 |url-status=live |journal=Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology |volume=18 |issue=6 |pages=527–542 |doi=10.1002/casp.965 |issn=1052-9284 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825032804/https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/casp.965 |archive-date=2023-08-25 |access-date=2023-08-20}}</ref>
=== Women-only parking spaces === {{Main|Women's parking space}} In several parts of [[Germany]] there are parking spaces reserved for women due to them experiencing higher rates of sexual assault. The law of some regions requires that 30 percent of parking is women-only. It has been debated whether these are discriminatory and promote the stereotype that women are bad drivers.<ref name="Noack 2015" /><ref name="South China Morning Post 2023" /> There is also women-only parking in Austria, Switzerland, China and Indonesia.<ref name="Noack 2015">{{Cite web |last=Noack |first=Rick |date=2015-08-10 |title=Sexist or not, women-only parking bays exist in Germany |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/motoring/news/71007511/sexist-or-not-women-only-parking-bays-exist-in-germany |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819051346/https://www.stuff.co.nz/motoring/news/71007511/sexist-or-not-women-only-parking-bays-exist-in-germany |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |website=Stuff |language=en}}</ref> In [[Seoul]], these were removed in efforts to promote gender equality.<ref name="South China Morning Post 2023">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-16 |title=Seoul scraps women-only parking spaces in diversity drive |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3210439/seoul-scraps-women-only-parking-spaces-amid-diversity-drive |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230819051342/https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3210439/seoul-scraps-women-only-parking-spaces-amid-diversity-drive |archive-date=2023-08-19 |access-date=2023-08-19 |website=South China Morning Post |language=en |agency=The Korea Times}}</ref>
